<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CloseAllFiles:
```c
int32 OS_CloseAllFiles(void)
{
    int32            return_code;
    int32            close_code;
    OS_object_iter_t iter;

    return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

    OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, &iter);

    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        /* call OS_close() on the entry referred to by the iterator */
        close_code = OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry(&iter, OS_FileIteratorClose);
        if (close_code != OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            return_code = close_code;
        }
    }

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 8.13 concerns pointer parameters that could be to const-qualified types. In this function the only places taking the address of a local object are the four calls above that pass &iter; each should be inspected to determine whether the callee actually modifies the iterator or could accept a pointer-to-const. There are no pointer declarations (e.g. T *p) or other address-of usages in this function to review. The scalar locals (return_code, close_code) and the non-pointer identifier OS_FileIteratorClose (a function pointer value passed as an argument) are not relevant for Rule 8.13 as written, so they need not be investigated here.
